question: Sulphur

question: Surface tension
answer: You can think of it as That property, due to molecular forces, which exists in the surface film of all liquids and tends to bring the contained volume into a form having the least superficial area. The thickness of this film, amounting to less than a thousandth of a millimeter, is considered to equal the radius of the sphere of molecular action, that is, the greatest distance at which there is cohesion between two particles. Particles lying below this film, being equally acted on from all sides, are in equilibrium as to forces of cohesion, but those in the film are on the whole attracted inward, and tension results.

question: Swastika
answer: One way to understand this is A symbol or ornament in the form of a Greek cross with the ends of the arms at right angles all in the same direction, and each prolonged to the height of the parallel arm of the cross. A great many modified forms exist, ogee and volute as well as rectilinear, while various decorative designs, as Greek fret or meander, are derived from or closely associated with it. The swastika is found in remains from the Bronze Age in various parts of Europe, esp. at Hissarlik (Troy), and was in frequent use as late as the 10th century. It is found in ancient Persia, in India, where both Jains and Buddhists used (or still use) it as religious symbol, in China and Japan, and among Indian tribes of North, Central, and South America. It is usually thought to be a charm, talisman, or religious token, esp. a sign of good luck or benediction. Max M distinguished from the swastika, with arms prolonged to the right, the suavastika, with arms prolonged to the left, but this distinction is not commonly recognized. Other names for the swastika are also known as fylfot and also known as gammadion.

question: Syllable
answer: One way to understand this is An elementary sound, or a combination of elementary sounds, uttered together, or with a single effort or impulse of the voice, and constituting a word or a part of a word. In other terms, it is a vowel or a diphtong, either by itself or flanked by one or more consonants, the whole produced by a single impulse or utterance. One of the liquids, l, m, n, may fill the place of a vowel in a syllable. Adjoining syllables in a word or phrase need not to be marked off by a pause, but only by such an abatement and renewal, or reenforcement, of the stress as to give the feeling of separate impulses. See Guide to Pronunciation, <sect/275.

question: Symbiosis
answer: You can think of it as The living together in more or less imitative association or even close union of two dissimilar organisms. In a broad sense the term includes parasitism, or antagonistic symbiosis _or_ antipathetic symbiosis, in which the association is disadvantageous or destructive to one of the organisms, but ordinarily it is used of cases where the association is advantageous, or often necessary, to one or both, and not harmful to either. When there is bodily union (in extreme cases so close that the two form practically a single body, as in the union of algae and fungi to form lichens, and in the inclusion of algae in radiolarians) it is called conjunctive symbiosis; if there is no actual union of the organisms (as in the association of ants with myrmecophytes), disjunctive symbiosis.

answer: In simple terms, this is One who attempts to unite principles or parties which are irreconcilably at variance;

question: Syncretistic
answer: In simple terms, this is Pertaining to, or characterized by, syncretism; as, a syncretistic mixture of the service of Jehovah and the worship of idols.

question: Syncrisis
answer: One way to understand this is A figure of speech in which opposite things or persons are compared.

question: Syncytium
answer: One way to understand this is Tissue in which the cell or partition walls are wholly wanting and the cell bodies fused together, so that the tissue consists of a continuous mass of protoplasm in which nuclei are imbedded, as in ordinary striped muscle.

question: Syndactyl
answer: It means Having two or more digits wholly or partly united. See Syndactylism.

question: Syndactyle
answer: One way to understand this is Any bird having syndactilous feet.

question: Syndactylic
answer: One way to understand this is Syndactilous.

question: Syndactylous
answer: You can think of it as Having the toes firmly united together for some distance, and without an intermediate web, as the kingfishers; gressorial.

question: Syndesmography
answer: One way to understand this is A description of the ligaments; syndesmology.

question: Syndesmology
answer: One way to understand this is That part of anatomy which treats of ligaments.

question: Syndesmosis
answer: It means An articulation formed by means of ligaments.

question: Syndetic
answer: You can think of it as Connecting; conjunctive; as, syndetic words or connectives; syndetic references in a dictionary.

question: Syndic
answer: It means An officer of government, invested with different powers in different countries; a magistrate.

question: Syndical
answer: It means Consisting of, or pert. to, a syndic.

question: Syndicalism
answer: It means The theory, plan, or practice of trade-union action (originally as advocated and practiced by the French Conf<eacute/d<eacute/ration G<eacute/n<eacute/rale du Travail) which aims to abolish the present political and social system by means of the general strike (as distinguished from the local or sectional strike) and direct action of whatever kind (as distinguished from action which takes effect only through the medium of political action) -- direct action including any kind of action that is directly effective, whether it be a simple strike, a peaceful public demonstration, sabotage, or revolutionary violence. By the general strike and direct action syndicalism aims to establish a social system in which the means and processes of production are in the control of local organizations of workers, who are manage them for the common good.

question: Syndicalist
answer: It means One who advocates or practices syndicalism.

question: Syndicate
answer: You might recognize this as The office or jurisdiction of a syndic; a council, or body of syndics.

question: Syndicate
answer: It means To judge; to censure.

question: Syndicate
answer: You can think of it as To combine or form into, or manage as, a syndicate.

question: Syndicate
answer: In simple terms, this is To unite to form a syndicate.

question: Syndication
answer: You can think of it as Act or process of syndicating or forming a syndicate.

question: Syndrome
answer: In simple terms, this is Concurrence.

question: Syndyasmian
answer: You might recognize this as Pertaining to the state of pairing together sexually; -- said of animals during periods of procreation and while rearing their offspring.

question: Syne
answer: In simple terms, this is Afterwards; since; ago.

question: Syne
answer: You can think of it as Since; seeing.

question: Synecdoche
answer: One way to understand this is A figure or trope by which a part of a thing is put for the whole (as, fifty sail for fifty ships), or the whole for a part (as, the smiling year for spring), the species for the genus (as, cutthroat for assassin), the genus for the species (as, a creature for a man), the name of the material for the thing made, etc.

question: Synecdochical
answer: It means Expressed by synecdoche; implying a synecdoche.

question: Synecdochically
answer: In simple terms, this is By synecdoche.

question: Synechia
answer: In simple terms, this is A disease of the eye, in which the iris adheres to the cornea or to the capsule of the crystalline lens.

question: Synecphonesis
answer: It means A contraction of two syllables into one; synizesis.

question: Synedral
answer: One way to understand this is Growing on the angles of a stem, as the leaves in some species of Selaginella.

question: Synentognathi
answer: It means An order of fishes, resembling the Physoclisti, without spines in the dorsal, anal, and ventral fins. It includes the true flying fishes.

question: Synepy
answer: You might recognize this as The interjunction, or joining, of words in uttering the clauses of sentences.

question: Syneresis
answer: You might recognize this as Same as Synaeresis.

question: Synergetic
answer: It means Working together; cooperating; as, synergetic muscles.

question: Synergism
answer: One way to understand this is The doctrine or theory, attributed to Melanchthon, that in the regeneration of a human soul there is a cooperation, or joint agency, on the part both of God and of man.

question: Synergist
answer: In simple terms, this is One who holds the doctrine of synergism.

question: Synergistic
answer: You might recognize this as Of or pertaining to synergism.

question: Synergy
answer: In simple terms, this is Combined action

question: Synesis
answer: You might recognize this as A construction in which adherence to some element in the sense causes a departure from strict syntax, as in <ldquo/Philip went down to Samaria and preached Christ unto them.<rdquo/

question: Syngenesia
answer: In simple terms, this is A Linnaean class of plants in which the stamens are united by the anthers.

question: Syngenesian
answer: You might recognize this as Having the stamens united by the anthers; of or pertaining to the Syngenesia.

question: Syngenesis
answer: It means A theory of generation in which each germ is supposed to contain the germs of all subsequent generations; -- the opposite of epigenesis.

question: Syngnathi
answer: In simple terms, this is A suborder of lophobranch fishes which have an elongated snout and lack the ventral and first dorsal fins. The pipefishes and sea horses are examples.

question: Syngraph
answer: One way to understand this is A writing signed by both or all the parties to a contract or bond.

question: Synizesis
answer: One way to understand this is An obliteration of the pupil of the eye.

question: Synneorosis
answer: You might recognize this as Syndesmosis.

question: Synocha
answer: One way to understand this is See Synochus.

question: Synochal
answer: It means Of or pertaining to synocha; like synocha.

question: Synochus
answer: It means A continuous fever.

question: Synocil
answer: One way to understand this is A sense organ found in certain sponges. It consists of several filaments, each of which arises from a single cell.

question: Synod
answer: One way to understand this is An ecclesiastic council or meeting to consult on church matters.

question: Synodal
answer: In simple terms, this is Synodical.

question: Synodal
answer: In simple terms, this is A tribute in money formerly paid to the bishop or archdeacon, at the time of his Easter visitation, by every parish priest, now made to the ecclesiastical commissioners; a procuration.

question: Synodic
answer: You might recognize this as Of or pertaining to a synod; transacted in, or authorized by, a synod; as, synodical proceedings or forms.

question: Synodically
answer: You might recognize this as In a synodical manner; in a synod; by the authority of a synod.

question: Synodist
answer: You can think of it as An adherent to a synod.

question: Synoecious
answer: You can think of it as Having stamens and pistil in the same head, or, in mosses, having antheridia and archegonia on the same receptacle.

question: Synomocy
answer: It means Sworn brotherhood; a society in ancient Greece nearly resembling a modern political club.

question: Synonym
answer: It means One of two or more words (commonly words of the same language) which are equivalents of each other; one of two or more words which have very nearly the same signification, and therefore may often be used interchangeably. See under Synonymous.

question: Synonyma
answer: You might recognize this as Synonyms.

question: Synonymal
answer: In simple terms, this is Synonymous.

question: Synonymally
answer: You can think of it as Synonymously.

question: Synonyme
answer: It means Same as Synonym.

question: Synonymic
answer: You might recognize this as The science, or the scientific treatment, of synonymous words.

question: Synonymic
answer: In simple terms, this is Of or pertaining to synonyms, or synonymic; synonymous.

question: Synonymicon
answer: One way to understand this is A dictionary of synonyms.

question: Synonymist
answer: You might recognize this as One who collects or explains synonyms.

question: Synonymize
answer: You can think of it as To express by a synonym or synonyms; to give the synonym or synonyms corresponding to.

question: Synonymous
answer: In simple terms, this is Having the character of a synonym; expressing the same thing; conveying the same, or approximately the same, idea.

question: Synonymy
answer: You can think of it as The quality of being synonymous; sameness of meaning.

question: Synopsis
answer: One way to understand this is A general view, or a collection of heads or parts so arranged as to exhibit a general view of the whole; an abstract or summary of a discourse; a syllabus; a conspectus.

question: Synoptic
answer: In simple terms, this is Affording a general view of the whole, or of the principal parts of a thing; as, a synoptic table; a synoptical statement of an argument.

question: Synoptic
answer: It means One of the first three Gospels of the New Testament. See Synoptist.

question: Synoptist
answer: It means Any one of the authors of the three synoptic Gospels, which give a history of our Lord's life and ministry, in distinction from the writer of John's Gospel, which gives a fuller record of his teachings.

question: Synosteology
answer: It means That part of anatomy which treats of joints; arthrology.

question: Synosteosis
answer: You can think of it as Union by means of bone; the complete closing up and obliteration of sutures.

question: Synostosis
answer: It means Same as Synosteosis.

question: Synovia
answer: You can think of it as A transparent, viscid, lubricating fluid which contains mucin and secreted by synovial membranes; synovial fluid.

question: Synovial
answer: In simple terms, this is Of or pertaining to synovia; secreting synovia.

question: Synovitis
answer: In simple terms, this is Inflammation of the synovial membrane.

question: Synpelmous
answer: You might recognize this as Having the two main flexor tendons of the toes blended together.

question: Synsepalous
answer: You might recognize this as Having united sepals; gamosepalous.

question: Syntactic
answer: One way to understand this is Of or pertaining to syntax; according to the rules of syntax, or construction.

question: Syntax
answer: You might recognize this as Connected system or order; union of things; a number of things jointed together; organism.

question: Syntaxis
answer: You can think of it as Syntax.

question: Synteresis
answer: It means Prophylaxis.

question: Synteretic
answer: It means Preserving health; prophylactic.

question: Synteretics
answer: You might recognize this as That department of medicine which relates to the preservation of health; prophylaxis.

question: Synthermal
answer: It means Having the same degree of heat.

question: Synthesis
answer: It means Composition, or the putting of two or more things together, as in compounding medicines.

question: Synthesist
answer: You might recognize this as One who employs synthesis, or who follows synthetic methods.

question: Synthesize
answer: It means To combine by synthesis; to unite.

question: Synthetic
answer: You might recognize this as Of or pertaining to synthesis; consisting in synthesis or composition; as, the synthetic method of reasoning, as opposed to analytical.

question: Synthetically
answer: One way to understand this is In a synthetic manner.

question: Synthetize
answer: One way to understand this is To combine; to unite in regular structure.

question: Syntomy
answer: One way to understand this is Brevity; conciseness.

question: Syntonic
answer: You can think of it as Of or pert. to syntony; specif., designating, or pert. to, a system of wireless telegraphy in which the transmitting and receiving apparatus are in syntony with, and only with, one another.

question: Syntonin
answer: You might recognize this as A proteid substance (acid albumin) formed from the albuminous matter of muscle by the action of dilute acids; -- formerly called also known as musculin. See Acid albumin, under Albumin.

question: Syntonize
answer: It means To adjust or devise so as to emit or respond to electric oscillations of a certain wave length; to tune; specif., to put (two or more instruments or systems of wireless telegraphy) in syntony with each other.

question: Syntonizer
answer: In simple terms, this is One that syntonizes; specif., a device consisting essentially of a variable inductance coil and condenser with a pair of adjustable spark balls, for attuning the time periods of antennae in wireless telegraphy (called also also known as syntonizing coil).

question: Syntony
answer: It means State of being adjusted to a certain wave length; agreement or tuning between the time period of an apparatus emitting electric oscillations and that of a receiving apparatus, esp. in wireless telegraphy.

question: Syphering
answer: You might recognize this as The lapping of chamfered edges of planks to make a smooth surface, as for a bulkhead.

question: Syphilide
answer: One way to understand this is A cutaneous eruption due to syphilis.

question: Syphilis
answer: It means The pox, or venereal disease; a chronic, specific, infectious disease, usually communicated by sexual intercourse or by hereditary transmission, and occurring in three stages known as primary, secondary, and tertiary syphilis. See under Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary.

question: Syphilitic
answer: You might recognize this as Of or pertaining to syphilis; of the nature of syphilis; affected with syphilis.

question: Syphilitically
answer: You might recognize this as In a syphilitic manner; with venereal disease.

question: Syphilization
answer: You can think of it as Inoculation with the syphilitic virus, especially when employed as a preventive measure, like vaccination.

question: Syphilize
answer: In simple terms, this is To inoculate with syphilis.

question: Syphiloderm
answer: You can think of it as A cutaneous affection due to syphilis.

question: Syphilodermatous
answer: You can think of it as Of or pertaining to the cutaneous manifestations of syphilis.

question: Syphiloid
answer: It means Resembling syphilis.

question: Syphilologist
answer: You can think of it as One skilled in syphilology.

question: Syphilology
answer: You can think of it as That branch of medicine which treats of syphilis.

question: Syphon
answer: You can think of it as See Syphon.

question: Syracuse
answer: You might recognize this as A red wine of Italy.

question: Syren
answer: You might recognize this as See Siren.

question: Syriac
answer: You can think of it as Of or pertaining to Syria, or its language; as, the Syriac version of the Pentateuch.

question: Syriacism
answer: One way to understand this is A Syrian idiom; a Syrianism.

question: Syrian
answer: It means Of or pertaining to Syria; Syriac.

question: Syrianism
answer: You might recognize this as A Syrian idiom, or a peculiarity of the Syrian language; a Syriacism.

question: Syriasm
answer: You can think of it as A Syrian idiom; a Syrianism; a Syriacism.

question: Syringa
answer: You can think of it as A genus of plants; the lilac.

question: Syringe
answer: It means A kind of small hand-pump for throwing a stream of liquid, or for purposes of aspiration. It consists of a small cylindrical barrel and piston, or a bulb of soft elastic material, with or without valves, and with a nozzle which is sometimes at the end of a flexible tube; -- used for injecting animal bodies, cleansing wounds, etc.

question: Syringe
answer: You might recognize this as To inject by means of a syringe; as, to syringe warm water into a vein.

question: Syringeal
answer: You can think of it as Of or pertaining to the syrinx; as, the syringeal muscle.

question: Syringin
answer: One way to understand this is A glucoside found in the bark of the lilac (*Syringa*) and extracted as a white crystalline substance; -- formerly called also also known as lilacin.

question: Syringocoele
answer: It means The central canal of the spinal cord.

question: Syringotome
answer: You might recognize this as A small blunt-pointed bistoury, -- used in syringotomy.

question: Syringotomy
answer: One way to understand this is The operation of cutting for anal fistula.

question: Syrinx
answer: You can think of it as A wind instrument made of reeds tied together; -- called also also known as pandean pipes.

question: Syrma
answer: You might recognize this as A long dress, trailing on the floor, worn by tragic actors in Greek and Roman theaters.

question: Syrphian
answer: You might recognize this as Of or pertaining to the syrphus flies.

question: Syrphus fly
answer: In simple terms, this is Any one of numerous species of dipterous flies of the genus *Syrphus* and allied genera. They are usually bright-colored, with yellow bands, and hover around plants. The larvae feed upon plant lice, and are, therefore, very beneficial to agriculture.

question: Syrt
answer: One way to understand this is A quicksand; a bog.

question: Syrtic
answer: You can think of it as Of or pertaining to a syrt; resembling syrt, or quicksand.

question: Syrtis
answer: In simple terms, this is A quicksand.

question: Syrup
answer: You might recognize this as Same as Sirup, Sirupy.

question: Syssarcosis
answer: It means The junction of bones by intervening muscles.

question: Systaltic
answer: It means Capable of, or taking place by, alternate contraction and dilatation; as, the systaltic action of the heart.

question: Systasis
answer: You can think of it as A political union, confederation, or league.

question: System
answer: You can think of it as An assemblage of objects arranged in regular subordination, or after some distinct method, usually logical or scientific; a complete whole of objects related by some common law, principle, or end; a complete exhibition of essential principles or facts, arranged in a rational dependence or connection; a regular union of principles or parts forming one entire thing; as, a system of philosophy; a system of government; a system of divinity; a system of botany or chemistry; a military system; the solar system.

question: Systematic
answer: One way to understand this is Of or pertaining to system; consisting in system; methodical; formed with regular connection and adaptation or subordination of parts to each other, and to the design of the whole; as, a systematic arrangement of plants or animals; a systematic course of study.

question: Systematically
answer: One way to understand this is In a systematic manner; methodically.

question: Systematism
answer: One way to understand this is The reduction of facts or principles to a system.

question: Systematist
answer: You might recognize this as One who forms a system, or reduces to system.

question: Systematization
answer: In simple terms, this is The act or operation of systematizing.

question: Systematize
answer: It means To reduce to system or regular method; to arrange methodically; to methodize; as, to systematize a collection of plants or minerals; to systematize one's work; to systematize one's ideas.

question: Systematizer
answer: You might recognize this as One who systematizes.

question: Systematology
answer: You might recognize this as The doctrine of, or a treatise upon, systems.

question: Systemic
answer: It means Of or relating to a system; common to a system; as, the systemic circulation of the blood.

question: Systemization
answer: You can think of it as The act or process of systematizing; systematization.

question: Systemize
answer: In simple terms, this is To reduce to system; to systematize.

question: Systemizer
answer: You might recognize this as One who systemizes, or reduces to system; a systematizer.

question: Systemless
answer: It means Being without system.

question: Systole
answer: You might recognize this as The shortening of the long syllable.

question: Systolic
answer: One way to understand this is Of or pertaining to systole, or contraction; contracting; esp., relating to the systole of the heart; as, systolic murmur.

question: Systyle
answer: You might recognize this as Having a space equal to two diameters or four modules between two columns; -- said of a portico or building. See Intercolumniation.

question: Syth
answer: In simple terms, this is See Sith, Sithe.

question: Sythe
answer: You might recognize this as Scythe.

question: Syzygial
answer: In simple terms, this is Pertaining to a syzygy.

question: Syzygy
answer: You can think of it as The point of an orbit, as of the moon or a planet, at which it is in conjunction or opposition; -- commonly used in the plural.
